metadata.titleEn: Long-term surface soil freeze-thaw states dataset of China using the dual-index algorithm (1978-2015)
metadata.description:
This dataset uses daily temperature data from SMMR (1978-1987), SSM/I (1987-2009) and SSMIS (2009-2015). It is generated by the dual-index (TB, 37v, SG) freeze-thaw discrimination algorithm. The classification results include the frozen surface, the thawed surface, the deserts and water bodies. The data coverage is the main part of China’s mainland, with a spatial resolution of 25.067525 km via the EASE-Grid projection method, and it is stored in ASCIIGRID format.
All the ASCII files in this data set can be opened directly with a text program such as Notepad. Except for the head file, the body content is numerically characterized by the freeze/thaw status of the surface soil: 1 for frozen, 2 for thawed, 3 for desert, and 4 for precipitation. If you want to use the icon for display, we recommend using the ArcView + 3D or Spatial Analyst extension module for reading; in the process of reading, a grid format file will be generated, and the displayed grid file is the graphical expression of the ASCII file. The read method comprises the following.
 [1] Add the 3D or Spatial Analyst extension module to the ArcView software and then create a new View.
[2] Activate View, click File menu, and select the Import Data Source option. When the Import Data Source selection box pops up, select ASCII Raster in the Select import file type box. When the dialog box for selecting the source ASCII file automatically pops up, click to find any ASCII file in the data set, and then press OK.
[3] Type the name of the Grid file in the Output Grid dialog box (it is recommended that a meaningful file name is used for later viewing) and click the path to store the Grid file, press OK again, and then press Yes (to select integer data) and Yes (to put the generated grid file into the current view). The generated files can be edited according to the Grid file standard. This completes the process of displaying an ASCII file into a Grid file.
[4] In the batch processing, the ASCIGRID command of ARCINFO can be used to write AML files, and then use the Run command to complete the process in the Grid module:
Usage: ASCIIGRID <in_ascii_file> <out_grid> {INT | FLOAT}.
The production of this data is supported by the following Natural Science Foundation Projects: Environmental and Ecological Science Data Center of West China (90502010), Land Data Assimilation System of West China (90202014) and Active and Passive Microwave Radiation Transmission Simulation and Radiation Scattering Characteristics of the Frozen Soil (41071226).
metadata.instructions:
Data naming format: the data set consists of 37 folders from 1978 to 2015. Each folder includes the daily surface freeze-thaw classification results of the current year. The daily surface freeze-thaw classification results are stored in the format of TXT. The naming rules are "smmr-ftyyyddd. TXT" or "ssmi-ftyyyddd. TXT" or "ssms-ftyyyddd. TXT", where yyyy represents the year and DDD represents the Julian day.
Data reading mode: all ASCII TXT files in this data set can be opened directly with a text program (such as notepad).In addition to the header file, the main content is the numerical representation of the freezing-thawing state of the surface: 1 represents freezing, 2 represents melting, 3 represents desert, and 4 represents precipitation.If the graph is to be displayed, it is recommended to use ArcView + 3D or Spatial Analyst extension module to read. In the process of reading, the grid file will be generated, and the grid file displayed is the graphical expression of the ASCII file.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to determine the freeze-thaw state of the land surface in China?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to determine the freeze-thaw state of the land surface in China involves utilizing daily brightness temperature data from SMMR (1978-1987), SSM/I (1987-2009), and SSMIS (2009-2015). These data are applied in a dual-index algorithm that distinguishes between frozen surface, thawed surface, desert, and water body states.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of datasets that use dual-indicator algorithms for freeze-thaw surface differentiation?
Feature Specification.Answer: daily brightness temperature data, frozen, thawed, desert, water bodies, spatial resolution of 25.067525 km, EASE-Grid projection, ASCIIGRID format

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution used in the data collection for the surface freeze-thaw dataset covering mainland China?

Definition.Question: What is the dual-indicator algorithm used for surface freeze-thaw discrimination?
Definition.Answer: The dual-indicator algorithm is a method that utilizes two indicators, TB,37v and SG, to distinguish between different surface freeze-thaw states. This classification includes frozen surface, melting surface, desert, and water bodies. It is applied to daily brightness temperature data collected from SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS sensors over the years 1978 to 2015, covering mainland China.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the classification of land surface conditions into freezing, melting, desert, and water bodies in data collection methods using passive microwave brightness temperature data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The classification of land surface conditions into freezing, melting, desert, and water bodies is influenced by the dual-indicator freeze-thaw discrimination algorithm using microwave brightness temperature data (TB,37v, SG). This methodology employs data from SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS, and the classification relies on specific threshold values determined by the indicators. The spatial resolution and the EASE-Grid projection format also play a role in how accurately these classifications are made.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of utilizing dual-indicator algorithms (TB,37v, SG) for distinguishing freeze-thaw states in land surface studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of utilizing dual-indicator algorithms (TB,37v, SG) is to accurately generate freeze-thaw classification results for land surfaces, which include frozen surface, melting surface, desert, and water bodies, using daily brightness temperature data. This classification aims to provide comprehensive insights into the freeze-thaw dynamics over the main part of mainland China, thereby supporting environmental and ecological research.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in using satellite brightness temperature data to distinguish between frozen and thawed ground surfaces in a dataset covering China from 1978 to 2015?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using daily brightness temperature data from SMMR (1978-1987), SSM/I (1987-2009), and SSMIS (2009-2015). A dual-indicator algorithm (TB,37v, SG) is applied to classify the ground into four types: frozen surface, thawed surface, desert, and water body. The classification results are stored in ASCIIGRID format, which can be visualized using ArcView software with 3D or Spatial Analyst extensions by importing the ASCII Raster file and converting it into a grid format for graphical representation.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the development of methods for classifying land surface freeze-thaw states using satellite brightness temperature data?
Enablement.Answer: The advancements in satellite microwave radiometry, specifically the use of instruments like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS, have enabled the collection of daily brightness temperature data. These technological advancements allow for the application of dual-indicator algorithms that use TB(37v) and SG to classify land surface freeze-thaw states into categories such as frozen surface, melting surface, desert, and water bodies.
